;印度和菲律宾外交部长周四承诺加强双边合作，因为他们双方一致反对中国在南海长期存在的领土主张，声称在“自由、开放和包容”的印度太平洋地区拥有共同利益。

;

;纽交所的会议传达了团结一致的信息德里，印度与菲律宾一起呼吁遵守国际法，即《联合国海洋法公约》，以及2016年国际仲裁做出的有利于马尼拉的裁决，反对北京对南中国海大片海域的主权主张。

;

;印度外交部长苏杰生和菲律宾外交部长恩里克·马纳洛共同主持第五届印度-菲律宾双边合作联合委员会后发表的联合声明表示，两位外交官举行了“广泛和就共同关心的地区和国际问题进行实质性的讨论，强调了“和平解决争端”的必要性。

;

;《联合国海洋法公约》是一项于 1982 年首次通过的国际协议，规定制定管理海洋及其资源的所有使用的规则，包括航行自由。 《联合国海洋法公约》有 169 个缔约方，规定了一个主权国家大陆海岸 200 海里的专属经济区。

;

;中国和菲律宾长期以来一直互相指责对方违反《联合国海洋法公约》，该国其他几个国家也指责对方违反《联合国海洋法公约》。该地区还基于自己的领土主张反对北京。中国、印度和菲律宾都是该条约的缔约国。

;

;北京对南海的主张以围绕多个岛屿和有争议海域的九段线为中心。 2016年海牙案件的裁决否定了九段线的合法性。北京拒绝接受不具约束力的裁决。

;

;多年来印度在这个问题上保持中立立场。然而，在 2020 年与中国有争议的边界发生致命冲突后，它称南海是“全球公域的一部分”。

;

;马纳洛周三将菲律宾与中国的领土争端描述为“重大问题”。与这个亚洲巨人的关系面临着“挑战”。但他补充说，“我们与中国的分歧并不是我们关系的总和”。

;

;如果美中竞争失控，菲律宾可能会成为“坟墓”：杜特尔特

;<马纳洛在新德里智库印度世界事务委员会组织的一次活动上发表讲话时表示，过去四到五年里，声索国之间一直在进行旨在制定南海行为准则的谈判”年。

;

;“我们可能看不到隧道尽头的曙光，但我们看到了隧道，那就是我们所在的地方，”马纳洛谈到这一努力时说道。

;

;周四苏杰生和马纳洛承诺继续在国防事务上合作。马尼拉表示，将考虑新德里提出的优惠信贷额度，以满足其“国防需求、采购海军资产以及扩大海上安全和救灾方面的训练和联合演习”。

;

;此外，两人同意在马尼拉派遣一名印度武官。

;

;“毫无疑问”：拜登与莫迪会谈中讨论了共同的中国挑战

;

;在宣誓之后表现出团结印度总理纳伦德拉·莫迪和美国总统乔·拜登上周在华盛顿举行双边会谈时表达了合作精神。

;

;白宫发表联合声明称，两位领导人“强调遵守国际法的重要性” ，特别是《联合国海洋法公约》中所反映的以及维护航行和飞越自由，包括东海和南海。

;

;华盛顿的共同防御条约盟友马尼拉于四月宣布将允许美国军队进入其领土上的四个新基地。这使得美军在那里的军事基地总数达到九个。北京回应称，美国在菲律宾增加军事存在“危及地区和平”。

;

;虽然美国对该地区没有任何领土主张，但它主张根据自己的主张享有无害通过权。航行自由。北京表示，华盛顿涉及军舰和飞机的行动违反了国际法。美国不是《联合国海洋法公约》的签署国。

;作为在美国（尤其是在加利福尼亚州）拥有许多亲密朋友的人，我对最近媒体报道的旧金山曾经著名的市中心区的恶化感到悲伤。我个人对这个地区很感兴趣，并在那里养了很多年的家。在香港开始我的职业生涯之前，我在洛杉矶县完成了大学学业，在此之前我在宾夕法尼亚州读了高中。我也一直与母校保持密切联系。

;

;旧金山市中心的问题似乎因各种因素的结合而加剧，引发了一场完美的风暴。催化剂是 Covid-19 大流行。封锁、保持社交距离的措施和在家工作的政策使人们无法外出，迫使许多企业关闭或大幅减少营业。

;

;疫情大流行后，许多人没有回来。相反，出于生活方式原因和方便，他们选择继续在家工作。对于科技行业的人来说尤其如此。

;

;他们的持续缺席阻碍了该地区的复苏，并加剧了办公室和零售店空置率的上升，而落后的交通基础设施导致了严重的交通拥堵，因为居民选择使用汽车而不是乘坐公共交通工具，这使得该地区更加不愉快。旅游市场低迷也加剧了问题。

;

;该地区的酒店、餐馆和其他依赖行人交通和旅游业的企业受到的影响是巨大的。 Park Hotels and Resorts 最近宣布停止为其旗下的旧金山联合广场希尔顿酒店 (Hilton San Francisco Union Square) 和旧金山帕克 55 号酒店 (Parc 55 San Francisco) 支付抵押贷款，实际上是撤出这两家酒店，这是一个重大打击，也反映出人们对酒店及度假村缺乏信心。旅游部门。这些物业加起来有近 3,000 间客房。

;

;相比之下，我们在香港就很幸运了。人们渴望返回办公室和正常的社交互动，我们正在经历旅游业的复苏。

;

;无家可归者长期以来一直是支撑旧金山市中心城市衰败的一个主要因素；该市是全国无家可归率最高的城市之一。旧金山市中心是震中，可悲的是，人们露宿街头或住在临时建筑中的景象太常见了。药物滥用现象屡见不鲜，居民们根本不会在车内留下任何物品，以免被盗。

;

;许多人相信 47 号提案（也称为《安全社区和学校法案》）的出台并通过了全民公投2014年，为小型犯罪和有组织犯罪的增加铺平了道路。某些重罪被重新归类为轻罪，受到的惩罚较轻。

;

;贫富之间的差距似乎正在扩大，高犯罪率推动了商业和零售租户的外流，以及主要购物中心运营商Westfield，加剧了城市的衰败。在发生一系列商店扒手袭击员工以及客流量减少后，许多零售商将当地条件和员工安全作为关闭的主要原因。人们普遍认为，许多小型租户正在等待租约到期，不太可能续约。该社区似乎将继续呈螺旋式下降。

;

;但我们不能忽视这样一个事实：旧金山有着自我重塑的历史，该市大部分地区的经济复苏正在进行中。市长伦敦·布里德承认市中心面临的挑战。今年早些时候，她概述了重新定义、重新构想和振兴该地区的五个优先事项：提供经济多元化和有弹性的就业引擎、热情、清洁和安全的环境、每天任何时候都活跃的充满活力的目的地、一个世界-一流的交通经验，以及支持所有人充分参与的公平经济。

;

;时间会告诉我们市长是否能够实现她的优先事项，并为这个曾经伟大的地区的复兴提供足够的资金和适当的政策。 11 月份亚太经合组织 (APEC) 峰会期间，这里将成为全球媒体的焦点，包括中国在内的领导人预计将在距离该地区仅几步之遥的一个地点出席此次峰会。希望在此之前能够出现早期明显的进展迹象，为该地区注入新的生机和活力，从而再次为旧金山人和游客的生活做出有意义的贡献。

;当Alphabet 旗下公司周四表示，要求互联网巨头向新闻出版商付费的法律生效。

;

;在 Bill C 法案之后，谷歌与 Facebook 所有者 Meta Platforms 一起宣布停止加拿大用户访问其平台的新闻。 -18，即《在线新闻法案》，已于上周通过成为法律。

;

;该法律预计将在六个月内生效。

;

;遗产部长巴勃罗·罗德里格斯 (Pablo Rodriguez) 介绍了去年的法案表示，平台不立即承担该法案规定的任何义务，政府愿意就监管和实施流程向他们咨询。

;

;加拿大媒体行业呼吁对科技公司进行更严格的监管以防止他们将新闻企业挤出在线广告市场。

;

;“我们现在已通知政府，当该法律生效后，我们将不得不从我们的搜索、新闻中删除指向加拿大新闻的链接。并在加拿大发现产品，”谷歌在一篇博文中表示。

;

;“我们不会轻视这一决定或其影响，并认为尽早向加拿大出版商和我们的用户保持透明非常重要”，它说。

;

;该法案概述了迫使 Facebook 和 Google 等平台就商业交易进行谈判并向新闻出版商支付其内容费用的规则，这一步骤类似于澳大利亚 2021 年通过的一项开创性法律。< /p>;

;欧盟以“滥用主导地位”为由命令谷歌拆分数字广告业务

;

;美国科技公司表示，这些提议对其业务来说是不可持续的。

;

;谷歌已经认为加拿大的法律比澳大利亚和欧洲的法律更广泛，称它对搜索结果中显示的新闻报道链接进行定价，并且可以适用于不制作新闻的媒体。

;

;这家搜索引擎巨头提议：该法案将被修改，以显示新闻内容而不是链接作为付款依据，并明确只有制作新闻并遵守新闻标准的企业才有资格。

;维珍银河周四成功将其第一批付费客户飞往最后的边境，这是一个长期的边境期待已久的成就，使其在新兴的私人太空飞行领域重回正轨。

;

;意大利空军军官展开国家国旗，向窗外凝视地球的曲率，同时在 85 公里（52 英里）的高度享受几分钟的失重状态。英里）。

;

;“欢迎来到太空，宇航员，”维珍银河的 Sirisha Bandla 在直播中说道。

;

;被称为“银河 01”的任务开始于一个巨大的双胞胎 -当地时间上午8.30左右，机身“母舰”飞机从新墨西哥州美国太空港的跑道起飞。

;

;运载机升到高空，大约40分钟后释放了一架火箭动力飞机，称为 VSS Unity，以近 3 马赫的速度飞入太空。

;

;美国宇航局和美国空军将 80 公里（50 英里）视为太空边界，尽管国际公认的边界称为“太空边界”。卡门线，高 100 公里（约 60 英里）。

;

;航天飞机机舱内有意大利空军的 Walter Villadei 上校和 Angelo Landolfi 中校、意大利国家研究委员会的 Pantaleone Carlucci 和 Colin维珍银河的贝内特。太空飞机上还有两名飞行员，舰载机上还有两名飞行员。

;

;直播显示 Unity 随后安全滑翔回地球。

;

;维珍银河的理查德·布兰森 (Richard Branson) 进行了历史性的太空飞行< /h3>;

;这次飞行是在维珍银河创始人理查德布兰森进行太空试飞近两年后进行的，旨在开启利润丰厚的太空旅游新时代。

;

;但该公司随后面临挫折，包括美国联邦航空管理局 (FAA) 短暂停飞，该管理局发现布兰森航班偏离了指定空域，而维珍银河没有按照要求通报这一“事故”。

;

;后来，实验室测试表明某些情况其飞行器中使用的材料已低于所需的强度裕度，因此需要对机队进行升级。

;

;该公司通过 5 月份的一次成功测试结束了太空飞行暂停，为周四的任务铺平了道路。在周四的商业飞行之前，它总共进行了五次试飞。

;

;银河 01 机组人员的任务是进行 13 项监督和自主实验，并收集其套装和机舱内传感器的数据。实验包括测量未充分研究的中间层的辐射水平，以及某些液体和固体在微重力下如何混合。

;

;维珍银河成立于 2004 年，已售出约 800 张未来商业航班座位的机票 - 2005 年期间售出 600 张2014 年，票价为 20 万美元至 25 万美元，此后又增加了 200 个，每人票价为 45 万美元。

;

;电影明星和名人是最先抢购座位的人，但该公司的计划在 2014 年遭遇了灾难，当时一架太空飞机在一次试飞中，飞机在空中解体，导致副驾驶死亡，飞行员重伤。

;

;该公司现在正在展望未来。下一个任务“银河 02”计划于 8 月进行，之后它希望每月进行一次太空跳跃。

;

;维珍银河重新开始太空票销售，新价格为 45 万美元

;

;维珍银河在“亚轨道”太空旅游领域与亿万富翁杰夫·贝佐斯的公司蓝色起源展开竞争，该公司已使用垂直升空火箭将 32 人送入太空。

;

;但自 2022 年 9 月发生事故以来在一次无人驾驶飞行中，蓝色起源的火箭已停飞。该公司在 3 月份承诺很快恢复太空飞行。

;

;与此同时，埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 的 SpaceX 已与合作伙伴公司合作，将付费客户送入更高的轨道、地球轨道或国际空间站。

;

;但是租用 SpaceX 火箭的成本要高得多。据报道，SpaceX-Axiom Space 联合任务中国际空间站的门票价格高达数千万美元。

;由其首领和金融家叶夫根尼·普里戈任向中国国家主席习近平发出了明确信号：中国与弗拉基米尔·普京领导下的修正主义俄罗斯建立“无限制”伙伴关系，双方旨在制衡美国及其西方盟友，这是一个冒险的赌注。

;

;乌克兰战争一直在削弱俄罗斯的地缘政治、军事和经济潜力。正如许多观察家所预料的那样，普京军事冒险的影响也在俄罗斯国内感受到。普里戈任率私人部队发起武装攻势，逼近莫斯科200公里，这表明俄罗斯在乌克兰的军事屡屡受挫而引发的俄罗斯内战不再令人难以置信。

;

;被西方边缘化由于对乌克兰的侵略，受内部不稳定和政治内斗影响的俄罗斯无法发挥重要的国际作用。莫斯科与西方的对抗尤其如此，这是中国与克里姆林宫接触的主要焦点。

;

;事实上，俄罗斯国际影响力减弱的初步迹象正在显现。上周，哈萨克斯坦表示将停止主持俄罗斯、叙利亚、土耳其和伊朗之间旨在解决叙利亚冲突的讨论，据报道此举令克里姆林宫感到惊讶。

;

;这表明，即使是俄罗斯的传统合作伙伴，例如叙利亚，后苏联时代的中亚国家对继续卷入俄罗斯地缘政治动态的前景越来越感到不安。中亚领导人从一开始就对普京对乌克兰的军事行动持怀疑态度，并且越来越倾向于与中国建立政治和经济关系，他们避免公开评论俄罗斯局势并非偶然。;

;如果俄罗斯继续对内衰弱，它将无法向海外投射力量，甚至在其传统后院也将失去影响力。

;

;除了中亚之外，莫斯科正在让步土耳其、以色列、印度、欧盟和美国等国家在南高加索地区的战略地位。

;

;此外，亚美尼亚和阿塞拜疆之间持续的领土紧张局势自普京袭击乌克兰以来不断加剧，有可能破坏俄罗斯与伊朗的伙伴关系。德黑兰传统上支持亚美尼亚遏制阿塞拜疆的军事扩张，而因乌克兰战争而分心的俄罗斯可能无法遏制阿塞拜疆试图确保通往土耳其领土的陆地走廊的安全。

;

;Students for Fair Admissions alleged that the adoption by UNC, a public university, of an admissions policy that is not race neutral violates the guarantee to equal protection of the law under the Constitution's 14th Amendment.

;The group contended Harvard, a private university violated Title VI of a landmark federal law called the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which bars discrimination based on race, colour or national origin under any programme or activity receiving federal financial help.< /p>;

;

;According to Harvard, around 40 per cent of US colleges and universities consider race in some fashion.

;

;Harvard and UNC have said they use race as only one factor in a host of individualised evaluations for admission without quotas – permissible under previous Supreme Court precedents – and that curbing its consideration would cause a significant drop in enrolment of students from under-represented groups.

;Affirmative action in US universities is unfair, not least to Asian-Americans

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 23:20:07 +0800 EU leaders debate Russia mutiny, pledge support for Ukrainehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3225995/eu-leaders-debate-russia-mutiny-pledge-support-ukraine?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.29 22:25;
;;

;European Union leaders gathered on Thursday to discuss the aborted mutiny in Russia and debate what role the EU could play in long-term Western commitments to bolster Ukraine's security.

;

;Arriving for a summit in Brussels, leaders said they remained committed to supporting Ukraine in the war triggered by Russia's invasion of its neighbour in February last year.

;

;“We have to prepare ourselves that this can last for a long time,” German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told reporters.

;

;“It's important that we consult and say we're ready to hold on for the long term, with financial and humanitarian support that's necessary for Ukraine but also when it comes to weapons,” he said.

;

;Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg joined the leaders for a working lunch and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky was also expected to address the summit by video link.

;

;The two-day summit is a regular gathering of the EU's 27 national leaders, with a range of topics including migration, economic security and relations with China all on the agenda.

;

;But the dominant topic is the war in Ukraine, with leaders also discussing how last weekend's aborted mutiny by the Wagner mercenary group could affect Russia.

;

;Several leaders said they would be keeping a close eye on Belarus, where Wagner chief Yevgeny Prigozhin has been exiled.

;

;Some also said the mutiny had weakened Putin but this did not mean the West could relax.

;

;“A weakened Putin is a greater danger,” EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said. “An unstable Russia becomes also a risk.”

;

;Many leaders stressed the mutiny was an internal Russian matter and the EU should press ahead with its support for Ukraine regardless.

;

;The nature of that assistance is also on the table in Brussels as Western countries work on a package of long-term assurances to provide weapons, equipment, ammunition, training and other military aid to Kyiv.

;

;A draft of the summit conclusions said the EU and its members were ready to contribute to future security commitments to Ukraine, to “help Ukraine defend itself in the long term, deter acts of aggression and resist destabilisation efforts”.

;

;Diplomats said France – a champion of a greater security role for the EU – had proposed the text, saying that the idea was to build on EU initiatives such as a fund that bankrolls military aid to Kyiv and a training mission for Ukrainian soldiers.

;

;But the text caused concern among militarily non-aligned EU members, such as Austria, Ireland, Malta and Cyprus, and among staunch supporters of transatlantic cooperation such as the Baltic states, who insist European security is primarily a matter for Nato.

;

;Where are Russia's top generals? Rumours swirl after Wagner mutiny

;

;“For us as neutral states it is clear we can't give security guarantees like that. Austria, Ireland, Malta and Cyprus have made it clear they have objections,” Austrian Chancellor Karl Nehammer said on his way into the summit.

;

;“We will certainly discuss this and we will find formulations that will be acceptable for us as well.”

;

;Countries including the United States, Britain, France and Germany are discussing possible security assurances for Ukraine ahead of a Nato summit next month in Vilnius, Lithuania.

;

;Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte said any EU role was still up for discussion.

;

;“We will have to discuss how far it goes, and if it would be lethal or non-lethal support. And we have to take into account that several EU countries are not a member of Nato,” Rutte said.

;

;Ukraine: Kyiv accuses local man of directing missile strike that killed 10

;

;Meanwhile, Poland plans to reinforce its eastern border following reports that Russian Wagner mercenaries plan to relocate to neighbouring Belarus.

;

;Polish Deputy Prime Minister Jarosław Kaczyński said on Wednesday evening that both an increase of uniformed forces and “fortifications to protect our border in the event of an attack” are planned.

;

;Kaczynski made the comments after a special meeting of a government committee on security and defence issues. He said up to 8,000 Wagner fighters could find refuge in Belarus, citing Polish intelligence.

;

;Poland, a European Union and Nato member, shares a 418km (260 miles) border with Belarus. In the late summer and autumn of 2021, the situation at the border escalated when thousands of people tried to enter the EU illegally.

;

;The European Union accuses Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko of bringing migrants from crisis regions to the EU's external border in an organised manner to put pressure on the West. Poland has since installed a 5.5-metre-high fence along the land sections of the border.

;

;Prigozhin temporarily occupied the southern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don on Saturday before leading his fighters towards Moscow, in what was the escalation of a long-simmering power struggle between the Wagner chief and the military leadership in Moscow.

;

;Some 200km from the Russian capital, the armed uprising was suddenly aborted.

;

;Lukashenko is said to have mediated the mutiny, with Prigozhin and his mercenaries reportedly promised immunity from prosecution by Russian President Vladimir Putin.

;

;According to Lukashenko, Prigozhin is now in Belarus. The Belarusian strongman has also offered the fighters of the mercenary force admission to his country.

;Twenty specialists have been approved to work in Hong Kong's public hospitals on short-term exchanges as part of a new global talent scheme to help ease the pressure on city doctors, health chiefs have said.

;The recruitment drive came as the city's public hospitals continued to see a high turnover of healthcare professionals, with more than 450 nurses lost in the past year.

;

;But the Hospital Authority on Thursday said it would continue to step up its worldwide recruitment drive to tackle staff shortages, including a new global healthcare talent scheme, which has already attracted the 20 veteran specialists from Europe, Southeast Asia and mainland China.

;

;Henry Fan Hung-ling, the chairman of the authority, explained the specialists would be expected to work at city hospitals for one to two years to strengthen professional training and at least 10 of them would come to Hong Kong by the end of this year.

;

;“All doctors coming to work in Hong Kong have to obtain a limited registration from the Medical Council, which would ensure their quality,” he said.

;

;Fan added the veterans would not take up places in the specialist training quota or promotion opportunities for city medical staff.

;

;He said the doctors would get the same salary package as city staff with equal qualifications.

;

;Fan revealed that by late April more than 2,450 nurses had joined public hospitals in the past 12 months, but about 2,900 had left.

;

;The staffing levels for doctors were a little better over the same period as 528 were recruited and 449 left, an increase of 79.

;

;The attrition rate was 10.9 per cent for nurses and 7.1 per cent for doctors, Fan added.

;

;“The situation is not ideal. While we went all out to recruit more doctors, we could not maintain a balance if we lost so many nurses,” he admitted

;

;“We welcome the government proposal to introduce limited registration for nurses, and would go overseas to recruit talent as soon as the bill is passed at the Legislative Council,” Fan said.

;

;Hong Kong makes over 130 job offers to doctors based in UK as part of hiring bid

;

;Nurses who had not trained in Hong Kong would be able to work in the city without passing the licensing examination under the proposal.

;

;They could either work with a limited registration, which would allow them to take up posts in nursing schools or care homes, or with a special registration, which would clear them for jobs in public healthcare settings.

;

;Authorities earlier flew to the United Kingdom and Australia to recruit doctors.

;

;Fan revealed a total of 59 doctors from the UK had been selected, and would join city hospitals in the second half of the year.

;

;He earlier said that more than 100 conditional offers were made on their previous trip to London.

;

;Fan added there were also 45 conditional offers given to Australian doctors and the authorities would start the selection process soon.

;

;The Hospital Authority also introduced a low-interest home loan scheme late last year to help retain qualified staff and had already received more than 1,100 applications.

;

;Successful applicants were given in-principle approval this month, which meant they could start house hunting.

;Hong Kong nursing body to decide eligibility criteria for new scheme: health chief

;“More than half of the applications came from positions with a high turnover rate, and the average age of the applicants ranged from 37 to 42 – the prime years,” Fan said. “This showed that the measure is effective in retaining talent.”

;

;Employees who have worked with the authority for three years or more can borrow up to HK$6 million (US$766,026), or four times their annual salary, with a maximum repayment period of 20 years.

;

;

;“While we strive to recruit talent globally, the local staff remain the core of the system as the number of people we recruited overseas could never compare to that of local workers,” Fan said.

;

;“The staff morale will not be affected either, as they are here to help, to relieve the workload, not to interrupt them.”

;Beijing should avoid acting blindly on Taiwan in the face of increasing pressure from the US, according to Sun Yafu, a former mainland official and influential figure for Beijing's Taiwan policy.

;

;Sun said mainland China was “facing more severe and complex challenges and risks” in cross-strait ties, and “high winds” and “even turbulent waves” were “still highly possible” – an apparent reference to the possibility of a military conflict.

;

;He made the speech during a forum on Taiwan issues in eastern Zhejiang province on Wednesday, with the speech published on the social media account of a cross-strait studies journal on the same day.

;

;Sun is deputy head of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, Beijing's semi-official group for handling cross-strait matters.

;

;'Shoot them down': Taiwan vows to destroy 'risky' mainland Chinese balloons

;

;The body was created in 1991 as an unofficial representative of the mainland Chinese government in its dealings with Taipei, which has a similar group for dealing with Beijing. The groups were established so the island and the mainland could interact without the official endorsement of the other side's government.

;

;Sun served as deputy head of the mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office from 2004 to 2013 and remains deeply involved in Beijing's policymaking.

;

;“In the current situation where opponents are surrounded and pressure is increasing, we should neither be anxious nor act blindly … We should not be shaken by increased pressure,” he said.

;

;“[We should] adhere to the direction and efforts of peaceful reunification, and at the same time strengthen preparations for military struggle.”

;

;Sun's remarks offered a rare look into Beijing's strategic and tactical thinking when it comes to handling its strained ties with Taipei.

;

;Military tensions have grown since Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen of the independence-leaning Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) came to power in 2016. Sun said the situation became “more severe” in 2021, after the US used the Taiwan issue to suppress China and “create a war atmosphere” in the strait.

;

;Beijing sees the self-ruled island as a breakaway province that must be reunited with the mainland – by force if necessary. Most countries, including the United States, do not recognise Taiwan as an independent state, but Washington opposes any use of force to change the status quo.

;

;Washington has accused Beijing in recent years of ratcheting up military pressure on Taiwan and speeding up its reunification plan, with some US officials speculating that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) could have the capacity to take the island by 2027.

;

;“The Taiwan Strait situation has undergone the biggest change since the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the United States in 1979,” Sun said.

;

;He blamed a shift in Washington's stance towards Beijing – from “a force that it could rely on” to its “biggest strategic competitor” – as the root of the present tensions and why the US “had to beat China down”.

;

;In recent years, Beijing and Washington have clashed over a wide range of issues, with Taiwan among the most sensitive.

;

;In his speech, Sun followed Beijing's official line, saying the US was mobilising its allies in the Asia-Pacific region, engaging in “military coercion” against the mainland and supporting the DPP in “speeding up war preparations”.

;

;Support for Taiwan's Tsai at 4-year low as #MeToo scandals rock ruling party

;

;Sun said frequent visits by US officials to the island aimed to “inflame war sentiment”, adding that Washington had upgraded its military support for the island.

;

;Since August, when then US House speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taiwan, Beijing has conducted two major rounds of military exercises near the island and its warplanes have frequently crossed into Taiwan's air defence identification zone (ADIZ).

;

;Sun said the mainland insisted that peaceful reunification was best and that “the use of force is the last resort when no alternative has been left”.

;

;Beijing introduced its Anti-Secession Law in 2005 to create a legal framework for it to use non-peaceful means to guard against pro-independence forces in Taiwan and the island's possible separation from mainland China. But Beijing has remained vague about when and under what circumstances the law would be invoked.

;

;Sun called on Beijing to take the initiative in opposing foreign interference, noting that the US and its allies “have challenged the rule that resolving the Taiwan issue is China's internal affair to create an excuse for its armed intervention”.

;

;He said Beijing should maintain “strategic confidence, strategic composure and strategic initiative” over the Taiwan issue.

;

;“We stand firmly on the moral high ground when it comes to national reunification,” he said.

;

;“Striving for peaceful reunification is not only to serve the needs of the overall national development strategy, but also our moral duty for national stability and the unity of compatriots.”
